newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany drafts multimedia law regulating Internet.
newsitem.headline: Germany drafts multimedia law regulating Internet.

text.p: Companies providing gateways to the Internet will not be required to police cyberspace for pornography or neo-Nazi propaganda under a draft law presented by the German government on Monday.
The legislation would make operators of online services responsible for their own offerings but stops short of holding them liable for third-party contributions.
Technology Minister Juergen Ruettgers told a news conference on-line providers would only be prosecuted for outlawed material they are aware of and have the technical means to prevent.

Ruettgers also said a separate part of the law will make Germany the first country in the world to set up a framework in which unforgeable digital "signatures" backed by a personal ID code would be legally acceptable.
"Providers will not be required to constantly search through their systems for outlawed material or material that could be harmful for adolescents," Ruettgers said.
"This is not meant as censorship," he added.

Germany had originally hoped to present the draft last spring. But it was delayed because federal and regional state governments only recently struck a compromise agreement to share in the jurisdiction of the law.

Executives at companies providing access to the Internet are likely to breathe a sigh of relief when they see the new legislation. Many had feared they could be held personally responsible for millions of pages created all across the world.

Internet regulation has been a particularly prickly issue in Germany. Child pornography investigators searched the Munich offices of access provider Compuserve last year and found several Internet pages they considered illegal.
Authorities are also investigating several other online services as part of a probe into pornographic and neo-Nazi material found on the Internet.
But so far prosecutors have not been able to bring any charges, partly because legal experts are unsure where new companies stand under laws drafted long before they existed.
Neo-Nazi propaganda protected under free speech laws in the U.S. is often illegal in Germany.
